channel.title: dotnet/AspNetCore.Docs Pull Requests
channel.description: Pull Requests from https://github.com/dotnet/AspNetCore.Docs, generated by https://github.com/meziantou/IssuesToRss/

item.title: PR: New JS interop - @guardrex
item.description:
Fixes #27016 Addresses #26364

Internal Review Topic

Notes

I'll number these points to make it easy for us to discuss the PR. You can just refer to a numbered point in your response instead of having to quote bits.

Pavel ... I'm just about out of time this week. If feedback is extensive ... or if you just want to table this for the weekend and get into the weeds with it next week ... no worries ... I'll be back first thing Monday morning.

  1. This gets the ball rolling with the base cases. I do cross-link your, Pavel, example. I hope :pray: we can avoid carrying whole sample(s) for any of this. Sample maintenance is a reader experience disaster (if they go stale) and very costly to maintain. Still tho, if that's your wish ‍♂️ Dan, I'll place Pavel's sample app in the dotnet/blazor-samples repo, cross-link, and maintain it.
  2. Code will live in the topic (code blocks) for release. Later, I'll come back and place the example code into the snippet sample apps at dotnet/blazor-samples.
  3. API doc cross-links for the new API won't be available until after release, so I'll circle around later and place links after GA.
  4. Dan, I'm not aware of the long-term plan for this approach to interop: Will it become a thing for Blazor Server? Is there a plan for this to replace JS interop based on IJSRuntime eventually? These things matter because they might change how the content is laid out in the Blazor node, now or in the future.
  5. I drafted this as a standalone topic (but it can be split easily into the existing topics if you wish‍♂️). Justifications ...
    • This doesn't have a special name. I named it ".NET JavaScript [JSImport]/[JSExport] interop" just to have something to distinguish it, based loosely on your, Dan, blog post comments. Even with the name that I gave it, it's a bit easier to see that this is a separate interop approach if it's in its own topic.
    • It probably is a bit easier for readers to get the whole explanation (calling both ways) if it's all in one spot ... one topic. We had to split call JS and call .NET into separate topics earlier because our original combined topic became iNsAnElY loooong , but I think we can have a single topic at least for .NET 7. Perhaps at .NET 8 ... especially if this interop approach starts to take over ... this topic goes away and the content is split: The opening bit here goes into the JS Overview topic, the call JS piece is for the Call JS from .NET topic, and the call .NET piece is for the Call .NET from JS topic.
  6. Pavel, I need the examples to compose in such a way that both the import example and the export example can live SxS in the same developer test app. I provide cut-'n-paste, fully working examples to readers whenever possible, and they're very popular . I ran into a problem tho ... I can't name the export module Interop and place it into the Interop.cs/Interop class file. It fails. I have to name it something else ... I use Interop2 ... to make it work. I don't understand why tho. Anyway, I'm for your help on that point. Just keep in mind that I'd like to compose this so that both the import and the export examples can go into the same app, in particular in the Interop class if possible, because I want to give devs a chance to play with all of the approaches in the same local test app.
  7. Pavel, I recommend that you and I try to get this as far as we can on our own before pinging Dan and Artak because they're usually ‍♂️ ... extra pings are generally good to avoid while we're just discussing and implementing improvements to this.

item.description:
Fixes #27052

Thanks @d4shm1r! :rocket: This will use line highlights, so the text part can avoid individual code lines.

and btw ... There's a number difference of line 16 vs. line 17. That's because I removed a comment line from the Program.cs file that's normally in the project template. It moves up that highlight to line 16 in the 7.0 example.

Fixes #27055

Thanks @SQL-MisterMagoo! ... I'll hold here for your feedback on the updates. I tried to steer it a bit more in the 'it may be required for you to control it' direction.

Also note that this is kind'a draft-y-ish at the moment. I need to run out for a couple of hours. I'll give it another ️ when I get back to perhaps provide further polish.

item.title: PR: [BULK UPDATE] DocuTune - Rebranding links - @alexbuckgit
item.description:
Global effort for the Microsoft Learn platform rebrand

The Microsoft team is applying changes to content for the Microsoft Learn platform rebrand. Changes include modifications to current Microsoft Learn and Microsoft Docs terminology as well as associated domain name and content URL path changes.

DO NOT MERGE THIS PULL REQUEST WHILE IN DRAFT STATUS! Some of the changes to links and other content are not valid until after go-live.

Please review this draft PR and provide any necessary comments as soon as possible. Because these fixes are tightly scoped, we have approval to automatically merge these changes to the default branch for publication.

This PR was generated via DocuTune. It includes only targeted fixes and minor formatting adjustments.

CorrelationId: d8c4c3ac-d49a-4c95-9ddc-9822ca297907 InitiativeId: docutune-rebranding-2022-09 PointOfContact: Alex Buck

item.title: PR: Address dotnet/docs #31084 - contradicting recommendations - @IEvangelist
item.description:
The .NET docs formally recommend not using the Microsoft.Extensions.DependencyInjection namespace, .NET docs: Options pattern guidance for .NET library authors — Namespace guidance. The sentence being removed in this PR are a contradiction to the .NET docs recommendation.

This PR removes the recommendation to use namespaces owned by Microsoft. Otherwise, doing so has a good chance of colliding with our future additions in these namespaces.

Fixes dotnet/docs#31084

item.title: PR: Clarify folder creation and add addl warning - @guardrex
item.description:
Fixes #26923

I'll make it utterly clear in the text to create the folder. I'm too scared to automate the folder creation step given that we know devs copy-'n-paste our code directly into their production apps . On production systems, upload folders ...

  • Shouldn't be part of the app's folder/file structure.
  • Should have execute permissions disabled.
  • Should have a virus/malware scanner in play.

Let's keep it manual for the local demo, but I do call out the folder creation step with BOLD text on its own line leading into the demo code.

I also improve the existing WARNING note at that spot (and add it to a prior version of the topic) on the dangers here. It includes a cross-link to our main security best practices content on file uploads over in the MVC file uploads topic.
